questions.prompt: In BG 2.2, what does Krsna point out to Arjuna?
choices: His military strategy is weak and will lead directly to defeat
He is showing weakness and sadness even though he is a warrior
His weapons are not strong enough for this particular difficult battle
He should have run away earlier from the battlefield and escaped
questions.feedback: Krsna tells Arjuna that he is acting weakly and unmanly despite being a warrior, and should overcome this weakness. Sometimes compassion based on bodily identification must be overcome. This teaches us that sentiment masquerading as compassion is not spiritual advancement.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.2, Srila Prabhupada explains three realizations of Absolute Truth using the sun analogy. Which realization represents the highest?
choices: Understanding the sunshine represents Brahman realization which is lower stage
Knowing the sun's surface represents Paramatma realization which is intermediate
Entering the sun planet represents Bhagavan realization which is highest
All three are equal according to impersonal philosophy taught by Mayavadis
questions.feedback: The bhaktas who realize Bhagavan are topmost transcendentalists, like those who enter the sun planet. Personal realization of God is higher than impersonal realization. This challenges the false idea that all paths and realizations are equal.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.3, what does Srila Prabhupada reveal about Arjuna's weakness?
choices: Arjuna's compassion represents genuine spiritual realization and advancement as explained here
Weakness arising from material attachment is different from spiritual humility
All forms of compassion are equally valuable spiritually speaking
Arjuna demonstrates perfect understanding of transcendental duty at all
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada distinguishes material weakness from spiritual humility. Arjuna's depression stems from bodily attachment, not soul consciousness. True spiritual humility means surrendering to Krsna's will while performing duty, not emotional breakdown. This challenges the false idea that all compassion is spiritual.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.11, what does Krsna tell Arjuna about mourning?
choices: A wise person laments for both the living and the dead equally
A wise person laments for the dead but not for the living at all
A wise person does not lament for either the living or the dead
A wise person should mourn continuously to show proper compassion
questions.feedback: Krsna begins His philosophical instruction by stating that the wise do not lament for either living or dead. This verse establishes the foundation: the soul is eternal and separate from the body. Lamentation based on bodily identification is a sign of ignorance, not wisdom. True knowledge eliminates grief by revealing the soul's immortal nature.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.12, what is true about the soul and individual beings?
choices: They are created only at birth and begin existence at that moment
They exist forever; there was never a time when they did not exist
They are destroyed when the body dies at the very end completely
They are all the same being without individual identity or uniqueness
questions.feedback: Krsna teaches that individual souls exist eternally; there was never a time when they did not exist and there will never be a time when they cease to exist. Each person maintains their individual identity forever.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.12, what does Srila Prabhupada teach about individuality in liberation?
choices: Individual souls temporarily exist but merge at liberation into the Supreme as explained here
Krsna, Arjuna, and all beings maintain eternal individual existence even after liberation
Only Krsna maintains individuality while souls become impersonal energy at all
Individuality is maya's illusion that disappears with spiritual advancement at all
questions.feedback: The Gita clearly teaches that Krsna, Arjuna, and all beings existed as individuals in the past, exist now, and will continue as individuals in the future. Our individual identity as a soul is eternal and never disappears.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.13, why does Srila Prabhupada say the instructor-instructed relationship between Krsna and Arjuna is meaningful?
choices: Both are on the same level of realization and spiritual understanding
Both are equally deluded by maya's influence and material energy
Krsna is superior, Arjuna is forgetful soul deluded by maya
Arjuna is the Supreme teaching the subordinate Krsna divine knowledge
questions.feedback: Krsna is the Supreme Lord, while Arjuna is a forgetful soul who needs guidance. This hierarchy allows real teaching to happen. For instruction to be effective, the teacher must have superior knowledge and the student must be receptive.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.13, what analogy does Krsna use to describe how the soul passes through the body?
choices: Seasons changing through the natural cycles of nature
A person changing clothes from old to new garments
A person passing from childhood to youth to old age
Water flowing from the mountains to the ocean below
questions.feedback: Krsna compares the soul's journey through childhood, youth, and old age to show that the soul remains the same while the body changes. Understanding this helps us not be bewildered by bodily changes.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.15, who is ready to reach a higher state of being?
choices: Someone who is disturbed by happiness and distress in daily life situations
Someone who stays calm and not disturbed by happiness or any distress
Someone who chases happiness constantly without any balance whatsoever in life
Someone who avoids all responsibility and runs from duty in life
questions.feedback: A person who remains calm and steady even when experiencing happiness or sadness is qualified to reach a higher spiritual state. Equanimity is a sign of spiritual advancement. This transcendental steadiness comes from understanding the soul's eternal nature beyond bodily pleasures and pains.

questions.prompt: According to BG 2.17, what is the soul compared to?
choices: The body and senses that we experience every single day regularly
Water and air elements that flow through the body all the time
That which exists throughout the body, cannot be destroyed, and is eternal
A temporary spark that exists only while the body lives temporarily
questions.feedback: Krsna describes the soul as eternal and indestructible, present throughout the body, and impossible to harm or destroy. The soul is fundamentally different from matter. Understanding this distinction is the beginning of spiritual knowledge.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.20, what is stated about the soul and birth and death?
choices: The soul is born and dies like the body always
The soul is born but does not die ever
The soul has never been born and will never die
Death is the end of everything that exists
questions.feedback: Krsna teaches that the soul does not have birth or death; it is eternal and is not destroyed even when the body dies. This understanding eliminates all fear. The soul's eternality is the fundamental truth upon which all spiritual knowledge rests.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.20, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about the symptom of the soul?
choices: The soul's presence is detected by bodily warmth and physical signs at all
Consciousness is the symptom of the soul's presence within the body
The soul manifests as intellectual capacity in human beings primarily
Only advanced yogis can perceive the soul directly through meditation
questions.feedback: Consciousness is the symptom of the soul. Like sunlight indicates the sun, consciousness indicates the soul's presence. This practical test helps us understand the difference between living and dead bodies.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.22, what does Krsna compare to changing clothes?
choices: Life itself and all its various stages and experiences
The soul's transition from one body to another body
Age and growing up from childhood to full adulthood
War and peace constantly alternating throughout all history
questions.feedback: Krsna uses the simple analogy that just as we change old clothes for new ones, the soul takes on a new body when the old one dies. This makes reincarnation easy to understand. This practical analogy helps us overcome fear of death.

questions.prompt: In BG 2.47, what is the main point about doing your duty?
choices: You should do your duty only if you are absolutely sure you win
You should do your duty without being attached to whether you succeed or fail
You should do your duty only if it brings immediate rewards to you
You should never do your duty if it seems difficult to accomplish today
questions.feedback: Krsna teaches that you should do what is right and your duty without worrying too much about whether you win or lose. This is karma-yoga - working without attachment to results.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 2.46, what false path does Srila Prabhupada warn against regarding Vedic study?
choices: Studying Vedas leads to material prosperity guaranteed by scriptural authority
Attachment to rituals only without knowing their purpose
Chanting holy names is for sentimentalists not for scholarly persons
Self-realization requires abandoning all Vedic knowledge and scriptural study
questions.feedback: One must understand the purpose of Vedas (knowing Krsna), not just be attached to rituals and heavenly elevation. The Vedas are meant to lead us to Krsna, not to material benefits. Those who stop at rituals miss the ultimate goal.
